sections.text:
Vol.:(0123456789)
Keywords Polyester · Nanocomposite · TGA  · Dielectric spectroscopy

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, hybrid materials from organic/inorganic materials gains intensive concern of researchers due to their unique properties [1–8]. Because of their capacity to behave as stabilizers or surface capping agents, organic polymers are great hosts for trapping metal and semiconductor nanoparticles. Due to the fascinating characteristics of nanosize and large surface area; nanoparticles are more attractive so, the polymer/nanofiller composites presented properties better than conventional polymer composites [9–14].
Polyester is the fourth most produced polymer, accounting for about 18% of world polymer manufacturing [15]. Recently, ferromagnetic particles integrated in polymer composites increasingly used as microwave absorbents at high frequencies [16–18]. NiZn ferrite has high saturation
magnetization, notable chemical stability, and excellent mechanical strength as one of the most significant magnetic materials [19]. NiZn ferrite nanomaterials showed good results for the attenuation of electromagnetic waves [20]. The ferromagnetic NiZn ferrite nanomaterials are generally useful in electromagnetic (EM) wave absorption owing to its natural resonance for EMI shielding materials. Nevertheless, their application is restricted by high density and hardness. Therefore, it continues a need for a comparatively lightweight, flexible, and effective NiZn ferrite composites for microwave absorption across broad spectrum of bands. Accordingly, magnetic composite materials generally prepared with ferro- and ferrimagnetic particles integrated in a polymer matrix are commonly used in electronic appliances and systems such as microwave transmitters, microwave inductors, and radio-absorbing materials [21–27]. Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles showed promising dielectric constant, dielectric loss, and saturation magnetization as reported in our previous work [28]. Consequently, we selected this ferrite composition for preparing polyester nanocomposites in the present work.
In this work, polyester/Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocomposites containing high concentrations up to 50 wt% were prepared by conventional solution casting method. The prepared
* T. A. Taha taha.hemaida@yahoo.com
1 Physics Department, College of Science and Arts, Jouf University, P.O. Box 756, Al-Gurayyat, Saudi Arabia
2 Physics and Engineering Mathematics Department, Faculty of Electronic Engineering, Menoufia University, Menouf 32952, Egypt
T. A. Taha et al.
1 3
761 Page 2 of 10
samples subjected to XRD, FTIR, FESEM, TEM, TGA, and dielectric spectroscopy measurements to study the structure, thermal, and dielectric properties of the nanocomposites. Also, the correlation between nanoparticles content and thermal stability as well as dielectric loss was considered.

sections.heading: 2.1 Preparation methodology
sections.text: Polyester/Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocomposites successfully prepared by the solution-casting method. First, the synthesis of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocomposites was done according to the procedure reported in our previous work [28]. Second, polyester obtained from local market mixed with acetone by magnetic stirrer then the Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles (0.0, 5.0, 10.0, 15.0, 20.0, 30.0, 40.0 and 50.0 wt%) added with continuous stirring until obtaining homogeneous solution. Lastly, the solution mixture transferred into a plastic Petri dish and put in air for 24 h to obtain the dried sample.

sections.heading: 2.2 Characterization techniques
sections.text: The structural characterization of the prepared nanocomposites were carried out via Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer (Germany) with CuKα radiation (λ = 0.154060 nm). Field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, Quanta FEG 250, Holland with EDX) was used to examine the nanocomposites morphology. The crystal shape identification was performed by transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL, JEM-2100) with 200 kV operating voltage. FTIR measurements were performed in the range (400–4000 cm−1) using Thermo Fisher Scientific Nicolet IS 10 spectrometer (USA) at a resolution of 1 cm−1. The thermal gravimetric measurements were performed from room temperature to 600 °C using TA instruments SDT Q600 TGA/DSC thermal thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The dielectric measurements were carried out at room temperature in the frequency range (0.01 Hz–20 MHz) utilizing broadband dielectric spectroscopy (high-resolution alpha analyzer (Novocontrol GmbH) assisted by Quatro temperature controllers providing temperature stability better than 0.2 K).

sections.heading: 3.1 XRD investigations
sections.text:
The X-ray diffraction patterns of polyester loaded with various contents of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles (0.0, 5.0, 10.0, 15.0, 20.0, 30.0, 40.0, and 50.0 wt%) are depicted in Fig. 1.
According to this figure, the nanocomposite of polyester/ Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 synthesized successfully, where the major peaks of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocrystals were detected at 2θ = 29.95°, 35.29°, 36.90°, 42.89°, 53.53°, 56.72°, 62.28°, 71.125°, and 73.98° with additional peaks of polyester at 2θ = 19.35°–25.05° which is consistent with findings of past studies [28, 29]. The average crystal size for all the samples estimated from the diffraction lines using Scherrer’s equation (D = 0.9 λ/β cos θ) to be within 26 nm [30–32].

sections.heading: 3.2 Morphological analysis
sections.text: The SEM morphological studies of the surface presented in Fig. 2a, b for polyester nanocomposites loaded with 10 and 30 wt% of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles, showed that the nanoparticles well incorporated in the polymer matrix with some agglomeration at high concentrations. TEM images for the same concentrations showed dark spots referring to the agglomeration of nanoparticles to form large flake-like micrometer-sized particles (see Fig. 2c, d).

sections.heading: 3.3 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy
sections.text:
FTIR spectra of polyester nanocomposites loaded with different ratios of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles (0.0, 5.0, 10.0, 15.0, 20.0, 30.0, 40.0, and 50.0 wt%) are shown in Fig. 3. It appears from the FTIR spectrum of polyester, characteristic absorptions band at 1732 cm−1 for carbonyl group (C=O), 3444 cm−1 for O–H stretching and 1642 cm−1 for aromatic C=C stretching. The peaks at 1161 cm−1 and 1261 cm−1 refer to C–O–C stretching vibrations. The peaks appearing at 2850 cm−1 and 2920 cm−1 are assigned to the methylene CH asymmetric stretching vibration [29, 33].
1 3
FTIR of polyester nanocomposites containing different ratios of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 denoted two additional absorption bands lower than 1000 cm−1. The higher band lies at 535 cm−1 and lower band lies at 423 cm−1, and these bands are assigned to the vibrations of the metal ion–oxygen complexes in tetrahedral and octahedral sites, respectively [28, 34–36]. The carbonyl group (C=O) detected at 1732 cm−1 shifted to lower wavenumbers (1727 cm−1) as the concentration of nano-Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 increased up to 50.0 wt%. This
finding revealed the enhanced interaction between polyester polymer matrix and Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles [37].

sections.heading: 3.4 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA)
sections.text:
TGA and DTG curves of polyester nanocomposites loaded with different ratios of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocrystals (0.0, 5.0, 10.0, 15.0, 20.0, 30.0, 40.0, and 50.0 wt%) are shown in Fig. 4. As indicated in the figure, each curve has one
T. A. Taha et al.
1 3
761 Page 4 of 10
degradation stage with peak temperature slightly changed within 356–385 °C. The addition of nanoparticles into the polyester matrix has a little effect on the peak temperature. The mass losses of polyester/Ni0.5Z0.5Fe2O4 nanocomposites decrease as the concentration of nanoparticles increases, these behaviour is in the lines of earlier literature [7, 38 ]. According to the data tabulated in Table 1, the integration of nanoparticles in the polymer matrix enhanced the thermal properties of polymer nanocomposite compared to the pure polyester. The increased thermal stability of the nanocomposites can be ascribed to high crosslinking density and secondary interactions imparted by Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 with the polymer chains [6, 7]. According to their contribution, the integration of nanoparticles in polymer matrix limited the movement of the polymer chains, lowered the free radical exchange and, hence, restricted the thermal degradation. The mass losses at various temperatures 200, 350 and 450 °C of polyester/Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocomposites are summarized in Table 1. These losses sured that the nanocomposites have thermal stability higher than pure polyester as the mass losses decrease with increasing the nanoparticles content. The present finding also support the strengthening of polyester/Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocomposites as the carbonyl group (C=O) detected at 1732 cm−1 shifted to lower wavenumbers.

sections.heading: 3.5 Dielectric analysis
sections.text:
The real part of complex permittivity (ε′) for all polyester/ Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocomposites decrease with frequency and becomes saturated at high frequencies, this trendline agree with the findings of other studies [34, 39, 40]. High ε′ at low frequencies might be on the grounds that the dipoles
have adequate time to get adjust to the electric field. Reduction of ε′ at higher frequencies may be due to the inability of the dipoles to align fastly with rapidly changing electric field. At very low frequencies up to 14 Hz, there is an overlap between the curves of different concentration of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles but after this value the ε′ increase with Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles which might be interpreted due to the decrease of charge carriers in polyester leading to the increase in the real permittivity. Also, can be basically attributed to a gradual formation of microcapacitor networks in the polyester matrix as the nanofiller increase. Moreover, this increase might be due to the accumulation of charge carriers in the internal surface of polyester matrix which can be demonstrated by Maxwell–Wagner–Sillars effects [40, 41]. Evidentially, at frequencies higher than 5.0 Hz the ε′ values decreased for the sample containing 50.0 wt% of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 which may be due to agglomeration of nanoparticles (Fig. 5).
The variation of dielectric loss (log (ε″)) with angular frequency log (ω) at room temperature for polyester nanocomposites at various Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles contents is depicted in Fig. 6. As given in the figure all specimens have the same behavior, as ε″ decreases as the frequency increases and becomes saturated at high frequencies. As the content of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles increased the dielectric loss increased. The frequency-dependence relationship of ε″ is given by the equation [42]
In another form
where m = − 4k T Wm , where s , ∞ , N, n, e, k , T , o,Wm are static permittivity, frequency limiting permittivity (infinity permittivity), concentration of localized sites, number of electrons, electron charge, Bolzman’s constant, absolute temperature, relaxation time, the energy required to move an electron from one site to the infinite and angular frequency, respectively, and B is a constant. By applying this model in the frequency range (1.0 Hz–2 kHz) to our results we can deduce the values of Wm listed in Table 2. It can be seen from the data in Table 2 that Wm values generally decreased with Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 content and are higher than that of PVC/NiO (0.025–0.027 eV) [40], but lower than that of PVC/La0.95Bi0.05FeO3 nanocomposites (0.66–1.11 eV) [43].
The Cole–Cole curves for polyester nanocomposites loaded with various contents of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles at room temperature are displayed in Fig. 7. Each Cole–Cole graph involved semicircle referring to multirelaxation processes. Therefore, fitting of these curves gives

the values of both static permittivity (εs), high frequency permittivity (ε∞) and dielectric intensity (Δε) that summarized in Table 2. From this data, we can see that these results higher than those observed for PVC/CuO [44], PVC/ NiO [40] and PVC/La0.95Bi0.05FeO3 nanocomposites [43]. Additionally, the polyester nanocomposites containing 10.0
and 40.0 wt% of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 have the highest εs and ε∞ values.
The relaxation time (τ0) can be calculated from the Cole–Cole analysis according to the relation [45]:
where v is the distance on the Cole–Cole plot between εs and an experimental point, u is the distance between the experimental point and ε∞ and α is a shape parameter that describe the symmetric broadening of relaxation. The relationship between ln ( v

and ln( ) was fit with a linear line as indicated in Fig. 8 and by knowing the slope (1 − α) and intercept of the fitting line ((1 − α) ln τ0), τ0 can be obtained and using this equation τ0 = 1/2πf0 we can estimate f0. The values of τ0 and f0 are tabulated in Table 2, which are higher than the observed values for PVC/CuO [44] PVC/NiO [40] and PVC/La0.95Bi0.05FeO3 nanocomposites [43].
The variation of ac conductivity (σAC) of polyester nanocomposites loaded with various contents of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles as a function of frequency ranging from 0.01 Hz to 20 MHz at room temperature shown in Fig. 9. As clear from Fig. 9, the σAC is frequency independent for the range 0.01Hz ≤ f ≤ 5MHz , strictly related to DC conductivity and after this range, increase rapidly for all specimens, which may be due to the increase in the mobility of charge carrier [46]. The enhancement of σAC with the addition of nanoparticles is explained on basis of the relative tendency of hopping of charge carriers in polyester/Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocomposites is higher than that in pure polyester. This high increment in conductivity may be due to the increase in the formation of continuous conductive pathways inside the polyester network [47].
Figure 10 presents the frequency dependence of real part of electrical impedance (Z′) of polyester loaded with various contents of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles at room temperature. The values of Z′ decreases as the loading of nanoparticles increases as well as with frequency and this behavior is the same for all nanocomposites. At low nanofiller loading,

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text:
Polyester/Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocomposites successfully synthesized and evidenced through structural techniques such as XRD, FTIR, SEM, and TEM. The Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles have average crystal size around 26 nm obtained from XRD analysis. FESEM micrograph indicated the good incorporation of nanoparticles in the polymer matrix. TEM showed that the nanoparticles flake-like micrometer-sized agglomerated particles. TGA analysis introduced enhancement in the thermal properties as the weight losses reduced with small changes in peak temperature. Both dielectric constant, dielectric loss, AC conductivity, and electrical impedance show frequency and composition dependence. The real part of complex permittivity (έ) decreased with frequency and enhanced with the addition of nanoparticles. The Cole–Cole analysis introduced the semicircle of relaxation

metadata.abstractText: This manuscript aims to investigate the structural, thermal, and dielectric properties of polyester/Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanocomposites. The synthesized samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), field emission scanning electron microscope, transmission electron microscope (TEM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and dielectric measurements. The XRD patterns confirmed the existence of both polyester and Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles peaks. FTIR analysis confirmed the incorporation of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 nanoparticles into the polyester matrix in agreement with XRD results. SEM micrographs showed distribution of nanoparticles inside the polymer and TEM image showed a little agglomeration of Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 with flake-like micrometer-sized particles. The incorporation of nanofiller into the polymer increases the thermal stability as the weight losses reduced with nanoparticles content. Dielectric analysis depicted the enhancement in both real and imaginary parts of permittivity when nanoparticles concentration increased. Additionally, the AC conductivity increased while the electric impedance decreased with increasing Ni0.5Zn0.5Fe2O4 concentration.
